TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a NORP citizen , born in DATE .

In DATE he and his brother were placed on the local child protection register because of “ known physical abuse ” . The cohabitant of the PERSON mother was given a police caution after he admitted hitting PERSON with a cane . Both boys were removed from the child protection register in DATE . The cohabitant subsequently married the applicant ’s mother and became his stepfather .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , the head teacher at ORG school reported to the local ORG that A. ’s brother had disclosed that PERSON was being hit with a stick by his stepfather . The stepfather was arrested on CARDINAL DATE and released on bail DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a consultant paediatrician , who found the following marks on his body , inter alia : ( CARDINAL ) a fresh red linear bruise on the back of the right thigh , consistent with a blow from a garden cane , probably within DATE TIME ; ( CARDINAL ) a double linear bruise on the back of the left calf , consistent with CARDINAL separate blows given some time before the first injury ; ( CARDINAL ) CARDINAL lines on the back of the left thigh , probably caused by CARDINAL blows inflicted DATE previously ; ( CARDINAL ) CARDINAL linear bruises on the right bottom , consistent with CARDINAL blows , possibly given at different times and DATE ; ( CARDINAL ) a fading linear bruise , probably DATE .
The paediatrician considered that the bruising was consistent with the use of a garden cane applied with considerable force on CARDINAL occasion .

CARDINAL . The stepfather was charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm and tried in DATE . It was not disputed by the defence that the stepfather had caned the boy on a number of occasions , but it was argued that this had been necessary and reasonable since PERSON was a difficult boy who did not respond to parental or school discipline .
In summing up , the judge advised the jury on the law as follows :

“ ... What is it the prosecution must prove ? If a man deliberately and unjustifiably hits another and causes some bodily injury , bruising or swelling will do , he is guilty of actual bodily harm . What does ‘ unjustifiably’ mean in the context of this case ? It is a perfectly good defence that the alleged assault was merely the correcting of a child by its parent , in this case the stepfather , provided that the correction be moderate in the manner , the instrument and the quantity of it . Or , put another way , reasonable . It is not for the defendant to prove it was lawful correction . It is for the prosecution to prove it was not .
This case is not about whether you should punish a very difficult boy . It is about whether what was done here was reasonable or not and you must judge that ... ”
CARDINAL . The jury found by a majority verdict that the applicant ’s stepfather was not guilty of assault occasioning actual bodily harm .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant ’s stepfather was charged with “ assault occasioning actual bodily harm ” contrary to section CARDINAL of the Offences against LAW , as amended . An “ assault ” , for the purposes of this section , includes an act by which a person intentionally or recklessly inflicts personal violence upon another . “ Actual bodily harm ” includes any hurt or injury calculated to interfere with the health or comfort of the victim ; the hurt or injury need not be permanent but must be more than transitory or trifling . The maximum penalty on conviction is DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . In addition , it is an offence under LAW CARDINAL to assault or ill - treat a child in a manner likely to cause him unnecessary suffering or injury to health . The maximum penalty on conviction is CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . NORP In criminal proceedings for the assault of a child , the burden of proof is on the prosecution to satisfy the jury , beyond a reasonable doubt , inter alia that the assault did not constitute lawful punishment .

Parents or other persons in loco parentis are protected by the law if they administer punishment which is moderate and reasonable in the circumstances . The concept of “ reasonableness ” permits the courts to apply standards prevailing in contemporary society with regard to the physical punishment of children .

CARDINAL . Physical assault is actionable as a form of trespass to the person , giving the aggrieved party the right to recovery of damages . In civil proceedings for assault , whilst the elements of the tort are the same as those of the criminal offence , the burden of proof of establishing that punishment was reasonable is on the defendant , on the balance of probabilities .
